item.title: Nippon Steel Says It Could Issue Equity to Fund US Takeover
item.description: Nippon Steel Corp. will consider a capital increase to fund its long-awaited $14.1 billion purchase of United States Steel Corp. and associated investment promises, the company’s vice chairman said on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Reina Sasaki, Tsuyoshi Inajima

media:content.media:description: Eiji Hashimoto, left, and Takahiro Mori, arrive at a news conference in Tokyo on June 19. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: New Zealand Pauses Cook Islands Funding Over China Deal
item.description: New Zealand has paused development funding to the Cook Islands after the tiny South Pacific nation signed agreements with China without the expected level of consultation.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

media:content.media:description: The region of Turoa on the Southern side of the Island of Rarotonga, the largest island in the Cook Islands is viewed from the air on August 30, 2012. AFP PHOTO / Marty Melville (Photo credit should read Marty Melville/AFP/GettyImages)

item.title: US Orders Social Media Vetting for Student Visa Applicants
item.description: The US State Department has ordered a review of student visa applicants’ social media presence and told them to make their profiles public, stepping up measures to restrict foreign citizens’ entry to American campuses over national security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Unrecognizable male student text messaging on mobile phone while being on a break in the classroom.

item.title: US Officials Prepare for Possible Strike on Iran in Coming Days
item.description: Senior US officials are preparing for the possibility of a strike on Iran in the coming days, according to people familiar with the matter, a sign that Washington is assembling the infrastructure to directly enter a conflict with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Saleha Mohsin, Catherine Lucey, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Israeli emergency responders search for victims amid the rubble of a damaged building following an Iranian missile strike in Bat Yam on June 15. Photographer: John Wessels/AFP

item.title: Thai Coalition on Brink of Collapse After PM’s Leaked Phone Call
item.description: Thailand’s government faces potential collapse after Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s leaked phone call unleashed fresh political turmoil, with the leader now facing calls to resign as she grapples with the exit of the second-biggest party in her coalition.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Envoy to China Calls Out Threat of Foreign Supply Chains
item.description: The US wants to revamp its trading relationship with China and the world by bringing many critical supply chains back onshore, the American ambassador to Beijing said.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: David Perdue with China's foreign minister Wang Yi in Beijing on June 3. Photographer: Zhang Ling/Xinhua/Getty Images

item.title: Unfrozen Loans Give Arce Hope of Easing Crippling Bolivia Crisis
item.description: Bolivian President Luis Arce plans to use overseas loans green-lit by congress to tackle crippling fuel shortages and soaring consumer prices before he leaves office in November.
item.dc:creator: Sergio Mendoza

media:content.media:description: Luis Arce Photographer: Marcelo Perez del Carpio/Bloomberg

item.title: US Says Rwanda and Congo Will Sign Peace Agreement on June 27
item.description: Foreign Ministers from Rwanda and Democratic Republic of Congo will sign a peace agreement June 27 in an attempt to end conflicts between the two nations that have persisted for decades, the US State Department said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

media:content.media:description: (Photo by Jospin Mwisha / AFP/Getty Images) Photographer: JOSPIN MWISHA/AFP

item.title: Irish Central Bank Cuts Economic Forecast Again on Heightened Uncertainty
item.description: Ireland’s central bank revised down its economic outlook for the second time in a row as heightened geopolitical uncertainty weighs on the small, open economy.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: The Irish Central Banks in the Docklands area in Dublin. Photographer: Patrick Bolger/Bloomberg

item.title: Chicago Allows Summer Curfews for Minors as Mayor Vows Veto
item.description: Chicago’s city council voted to give its police chief the green light to enforce temporary curfews for minors in a bid to curb violence that has typically ramped up during the summer months, prompting Mayor Brandon Johnson to vow to block the measure.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Davis

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk along the Concrete Beach in Chicago, Illinois, US, on Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024. Chicago is delaying its $643 million bond sale that was expected to price last week amid volatility in the $4 trillion market for state and local bonds.

item.title: Trump Wraps Situation Room Meeting as Iran Plan Remains Mystery
item.description: President Donald Trump concluded a meeting Wednesday with top advisers as he weighed whether to plunge the US into the ongoing war between Israel and Iran, but the White House offered few clues about whether he had decided to join the offensive aimed at destroying Tehran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jordan Fabian

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises following an Israeli strike in Tehran on June 17. Photographer: Atta Kenare/Getty Images

item.title: Pakistan Army Chief Discusses Israel-Iran Conflict With Trump
item.description: President Donald Trump met Pakistan’s army chief Wednesday in Washington as the US considers supporting Israeli airstrikes on Iran, a country with a cooperative and complex relationship with the government in Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Faseeh Mangi, Derek Wallbank

media:content.media:description: Asim Munir Photographer: Iranian Presidency/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

item.title: Colombian High Court Blocks Petro’s Referendum on Labor Rights
item.description: One of Colombia’s highest courts blocked President Gustavo Petro’s proposal to hold a referendum on boosting labor rights.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro, Colombia’s president, speaks during a rally at Bolivar Square in Bogota, Colombia, on Thursday, May 1, 2025. Petro presented a bill on Thursday that seeks to submit proposals for labor rights and working conditions to a public referendum after Congress rejected his labor reform earlier this year.

item.title: Trump Tells Supreme Court No Need to Rush to Consider Tariffs
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration urged the US Supreme Court to turn away a request for fast-track review of his sweeping tariffs, saying the justices should give lower courts more time to weigh in.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds a reciprocal tariffs poster during a tariff announcement in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 2, 2025. Trump is imposing tariffs on US trading partners worldwide, his biggest assault yet on a global economic system he has long bemoaned as unfair.

item.title: Senate Republicans Float Rural Hospital Fund to Ease Impasse Over Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans are crafting provisions to provide funding for struggling rural hospitals in order to resolve an impasse on Medicaid changes that is one issue holding up passage of President Donald Trump’s tax-cut bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Erin Durkin, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: A trucks drives towards a sign pointing to the emergency room entrance at OSF Saint Paul Medical Center in Mendota, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, April 14, 2020. Hospitals are facing shortages of masks, gowns, gloves, tests, ventilators, cleaning supplies and toilet paper, a federal survey of hospital administrators conducted in late March found.

item.title: Social Security Warns of 23% Benefit Cut by 2034 Without a Fix
item.description: The Social Security trust fund will become unable to pay scheduled benefits to retirees and the disabled as soon as 2034, new projections show — one year earlier than last year’s estimates.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: The US Social Security Administration headquarters in Woodlawn, Maryland.

item.title: Trump’s Iran War Talk Testing His Ties With MAGA Loyalists
item.description: Donald Trump’s hints that he may dispatch the US military to help Israel destroy Iran’s nuclear program has spurred a revolt from his typically faithful America First base, further dividing a party already struggling to unite around the president’s second-term agenda.
item.dc:creator: Mario Parker, Jamie Tarabay, Nancy Cook

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Trump Sees His MAGA Base Dividing Over Iran
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Joe Sobczyk looks at the rift among Trump supporters over what to do about Iran. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Joe Sobczyk

item.title: Here's Where NYC Mayoral Candidates Stand on Key Issues
item.description: For the full experience visit: Here's Where NYC Mayoral Candidates Stand on Key Issues
item.dc:creator: Jennah Haque, Laura Nahmias, Elena Mejia, Rafael Garcia

item.title: Czech Government Wins Confidence Vote Months Ahead of Election
item.description: The Czech government survived a confidence vote initiated by the opposition over a Bitcoin scandal, shouldering through the turmoil ahead of a parliamentary election scheduled for October.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Dudik

media:content.media:description: Petr Fiala, Czech Republic's prime minister, during an interview at the parliament in Prague, Czech Republic, on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024. Fiala, whose government has been among the most vocal in NATO in denouncing the Kremlin’s invasion of Ukraine, said forcing Kyiv to cede territory will only encourage Vladimir Putin’s war machine.

item.title: Trump Again Pushes TikTok Sale Deadline With 90-Day Reprieve
item.description: President Donald Trump plans to extend for a third time the deadline for Chinese company ByteDance Ltd. to divest the American operations of TikTok, allowing the social media app to keep running in the US while negotiations proceed.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: TikTok Inc. offices in Culver City, California

item.title: Kirchner Begins Her House Arrest: ‘Can I Go Out to My Balcony or Not?’
item.description: Former President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner started her first full day of house arrest wondering what she can actually do at her home in Argentina’s capital for the next six years.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Gillespie

media:content.media:description: Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner waves from her balcony in Buenos Aires, on June 11.

item.title: Why Oil Prices Are Decoupling From Geopolitical Threats
item.description: On this episode of Trumponomics, we discuss how Israel’s surprise attack on Iran and the resulting war aren’t having the expected effects on energy markets.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Mandatory Credit: Photo by Ahmad Hatefi/UPI/Shutterstock (15358532t) Iranians looking as a plume of heavy smoke and fire rise from an oil refinery in Tehran, after it was hit in an overnight Israeli strike, on Sunday on June 15, 2025. An Israeli Attack on An Oil Depot in Tehran, Iran - 15 Jun 2025

item.title: Trump Urges SALT Deal as Lawler Stands Firm on $40,000 Cap
item.description: President Donald Trump expressed optimism that lawmakers could reach a compromise on the state and local tax deduction — a sticking point in his “One Big Beautiful Bill” — even as a key SALT advocate insisted a deal had already been reached.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Skylar Woodhouse, Joe Mathieu

media:content.media:description: Representative Mike Lawler

item.title: Trump Targets Fertilizer Plant to Tighten Screws on Maduro
item.description: One of Venezuela’s most valuable overseas assets is set to lose a license that allows it to operate in Colombia, amid a US attack on the finances of the Nicolas Maduro regime.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago, Patricia Laya, Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: A ship arrives at the dock of the Monomeros fertilizer company in Barranquilla, Colombia.

item.title: Merz Upbeat on State Backing for €46 Billion Tax-Break Package
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz said he’s confident Germany’s regional governments will back his €46 billion ($53 billion) package of tax breaks after progress toward settling a dispute over sharing the cost.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz at the Bundestag in Berlin.

item.title: Pakistan Army Chief Set for Rare Meeting With US President
item.description: President Donald Trump is expected to meet Pakistan’s army chief for talks as the US considers supporting Israeli airstrikes on Iran, a country with a cooperative and complex relationship with the government in Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank, Faseeh Mangi

media:content.media:description: Asim Munir Photographer: Iranian Presidency/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

item.title: Supreme Court Upholds Curbs on Care for Transgender Minors
item.description: A divided US Supreme Court upheld a Tennessee law that outlaws certain controversial medical treatments for transgender children, preserving similar measures in two dozen states and dealing a fresh blow to LGBTQ rights.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: LGBT activists and supporters rally in support of transgender people at New York City Hall.

item.title: Modi Disputes Trump’s Version of India-Pakistan Ceasefire
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi disputed President Donald Trump’s claims that trade deals were used to clinch a recent ceasefire with Pakistan, the latest sign of possible strain in the relationship between New Delhi and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta, Prateek Mazumdar, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi

item.title: Thai Conservative Party Quits Ruling Coalition in Blow to PM
item.description: The second-largest party in Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s government quit the ruling coalition, a major setback for the leader facing calls for resignation after blaming her own military for escalating a border dispute with neighbor Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra
